article.body: Shares in Sunrise Communications soared more than 26% on Wednesday, to hit a record high after John Maloneâs Liberty Global launched an all-cash takeover offer for the Swiss telecoms business in a deal valued at SFr6.8 billion ($7.4 billion), including debt. Denver-based Liberty Global LBTYA, +6.10% Â will pay SFr110 to acquire Sunrise SRCG, +0.27%, representing a 28% premium to the Swiss telecom companyâs closing share price of CHF86.20 on Tuesday. The deal will be funded from Liberty Globalâs cash reserves and debt. Mike Fries, Liberty Global Chief Executive, said the takeover of Sunrise would create a competitor to incumbent player state-controlled telecoms group Swisscom SCMN, +0.02%. He said Liberty Global would consider a SRCG, +0.27% flotation of Sunrise in the future, once the takeover is completed and the operations are running smoothly and some synergies have been realized. âI think that is a very good chance of happening. We donât have a problem with publicly listed companies. Our operating company in Belgium is a publicly listed company, of course,â Fries said, adding that Swiss investors generally are attracted to local companies, especially in the telecom space, which have strong and sustainable cash flows. Shares in Sunrise Communications were trading almost 26% higher to 108.6 francs in early morning European trading. The combined business would have SFr3.17 billion in revenue, 2.1 million mobile postpaid subscribers, 1.2 million broadband subscribers and 1.3 million television subscribers, reflecting approximately 30% market share in each segment, Liberty Global said. âThe industrial logic of this merger is undeniable,â Fries said. The takeover comes less than a year after Denver-based Liberty Global was forced to scrap the attempted $6.4 billion sale of its Swiss cable business UPC to Sunrise Communications Group after Germanyâs Freenet â Sunriseâs biggest shareholder, with 24% of the stock â and influential proxy adviser Institutional Shareholder Services, opposed the deal. Freenet FNTN, -0.98% Â is backing the sale of Sunrise to Liberty Global. Libertyâs billionaire chairman Malone has been on an mergers and acquisitions spree since the late 1990s, earning him the âCable Cowboyâ moniker. The group has carried out more than 370 transactions since 2005. The group built up a $12 billion cash acquisition war chest in 2018, after selling its German and Eastern European cable assets to Vodafone Group VOD, -0.05% for $21.8 billion.
